transcript:
Patient: Setting boundaries at work has been challenging. I find myself taking on more than I can handle and struggling to say no when I need to. I'm worried about disappointing my colleagues or seeming like I'm not a team player.

Therapist: It's common to struggle with setting boundaries, especially in a work environment where we want to be seen as capable and reliable. However, consistently taking on too much can lead to burnout and increased stress, which ultimately impacts our overall well-being and productivity. Let's explore some strategies for setting boundaries in a way that feels comfortable and assertive.

One technique is to use "I" statements to express your needs and limits. For example, instead of simply saying "no" to a request, you could say something like, "I'm currently working on several projects and need to prioritize my workload to ensure I can complete everything to the best of my ability. I won't be able to take on this additional task at the moment."

Patient: That makes sense. Using "I" statements feels less confrontational and more focused on my own needs and limitations.

Therapist: Exactly. It's about clearly and calmly communicating your needs while still showing that you value your work and colleagues. Another strategy is to offer alternative solutions when possible. If you can't take on a particular task, perhaps you can suggest someone else who might be able to help or offer a compromise that works for both you and your colleague.

Patient: Offering alternative solutions is a good idea. It shows that I'm still trying to be helpful and supportive, even if I can't personally take on the task.

Therapist: Yes, and it can help maintain positive working relationships while still setting necessary boundaries. Remember, setting boundaries is a skill that takes practice. It's okay to start small and build up your confidence over time. We can role-play some scenarios in our sessions to help you feel more prepared.

Patient: Role-playing could be really helpful. I think practicing these conversations in a safe space would make it easier to implement them in real-life situations.

Therapist: Absolutely. We can practice different scenarios and discuss various ways to respond assertively. Over time, setting boundaries will start to feel more natural and comfortable.

Patient: I'm definitely willing to give it a try. I know that setting boundaries is important for my well-being, and I want to work on prioritizing that.

Therapist: That's a great goal, Emilio. Remember, setting boundaries is an act of self-care and helps ensure that you can show up as your best self, both at work and in your personal life. It's not selfish to prioritize your own needs and well-being.

Patient: I guess I never really thought of it that way. I always felt like I needed to put others' needs before my own, but I can see how that's not sustainable in the long run.

Therapist: It's a common belief, but it's not a healthy or sustainable one. Everyone's needs and limits are valid, including your own. Learning to balance your own needs with the needs of others is key to building healthy relationships and maintaining your mental health.

Patient: That makes a lot of sense. I'm starting to see how my thoughts and beliefs about setting boundaries have been influencing my emotions and behaviors at work.

Therapist: That's a great insight, Emilio. Recognizing those connections between thoughts, feelings, and behaviors is a crucial part of CBT. As we continue to work together, we'll explore those connections further and develop strategies for reframing unhelpful thoughts and beliefs.

Patient: I'm looking forward to continuing this work. I know it won't be easy, but I'm committed to making changes to improve my mental health and overall well-being.

Therapist: Your commitment and willingness to engage in this process are essential to your success, Emilio. Remember, change takes time, and there will be ups and downs along the way. Be patient and compassionate with yourself as you navigate this journey.

Patient: Thank you for the reminder. I'll try to keep that in mind as I continue to practice these skills and work on setting boundaries.

Therapist: You're welcome, Emilio. I'm here to support you every step of the way. Let's continue to explore how your thoughts and beliefs about setting boundaries have been shaped by your cultural background and family dynamics. This can help us develop a more comprehensive understanding of your experiences and tailor our strategies accordingly.
